item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Head of Graft-Fighting Agency Is Latest to Be Fired by the President
item.description: President Muhammadu Buhari took office in May promising to halt the graft dragging the country down.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Police Investigate Killing of a Sea Lion at the Dortmund Zoo
item.description: A 21-year-old sea lion named Holly was found beaten to death in her enclosure on Friday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: Official Says Delayed Deal to Sell Iran Missiles Remains in Force
item.description: An announcement by Sergei V. Chemezov, Russia’s chief arms trade executive, provided no delivery date or any other details.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Obama and Netanyahu Seek to Move Past Rift Over Iran Nuclear Deal
item.description: In their first encounter since their feud over the Iran nuclear deal, President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke of their shared goals.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Invitation List Looms as Test for Syria Talks
item.description: When world powers gather in Vienna this weekend to discuss a possible postwar political deal for Syria, one of the main points of contention will be to determine which opposition groups are legitimate and which are terrorists.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: NATO War Games Unwittingly Put Soviets and U.S. on ‘Hair Trigger’ in ’83, Analysis Suggests
item.description: A newly declassified document says that Soviet military leaders may have thought that the Able Archer training exercise was a cover for a real attack.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: Stonehenge Begins to Yield Its Secrets
item.description: Discoveries over the last decade have revealed more about the everyday lives of the people for whom the giant monuments held meaning.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG
item.media:description: Discoveries in the past decade have revealed more about the people for whom Stonehenge and nearby monuments held great meaning

item.title: ISIS Ally in Egypt Emerges as Key Suspect in Russian Jet Crash
item.description: Officials say they believe it increasingly likely that a group known as the Sinai Province of the Islamic State planted a bomb on the Russian airliner that crashed in Egypt, killing 224 people.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Sinai Province of the Islamic State
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Egypt Extends Detention of a Journalist, Hossam Bahgat
item.description: The journalist was interrogated Sunday about his article on an alleged coup plot by military officers and then was moved to a secret detention center.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Myanmar Election Has Aung San Suu Kyi’s Party Confident of Landslide
item.description: The military-backed ruling party acknowledged its poor showing in the landmark elections, whose results were still being tabulated on Monday.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of the National League for Democracy party celebrated election results displayed on a giant TV screen in Yangon, Myanmar, on Monday.

item.title: Russian Artist Sets Security Service’s Door on Fire
item.description: In his latest act of protest, Pyotr Pavlensky set fire to the entrance of Russia’s Federal Security Service and was charged with vandalism.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Jordanian Police Officer Kills Five, Including Two Americans
item.description: The officer was shot to death after opening fire at a training center in eastern Amman, the Jordanian capital. The motive was not immediately clear..
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS and DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Afghan Fighters Loyal to ISIS Beheaded 7 Hostages, Officials Say
item.description: The bodies of seven ethnic Hazara civilians were found Saturday after the Taliban had pushed back the militants and a group of allied dissidents, officials said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and TAIMOOR SHAH
item.media:description: The bodies of Hazara civilians, reportedly killed by Islamic State militants in Zabul, Afghanistan, were brought to their hometown in Ghazni.

item.title: Catalan Legislators Raise Stakes in Push for Secession From Spain
item.description: In the latest step to break with Spain, legislators approved a resolution for creating separate Catalan institutions, including a tax agency and social security system.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Creditors Withhold 2 Billion Euro Bailout Payment From Greece
item.description: As Greece tries to secure the next installment from its $92 billion package, Greek officials and foreign creditors remain at odds over whether Athens has met economic overhaul targets.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Luis de Guindos, Spain’s economy minister, and Euclid Tsakalotos in Brussels on Monday.

item.title: An Island Refuge, Surrounded by Bloody Civil War, in South Sudan
item.description: Tens of thousands of desperate civilians have sought safety in a swamp that is full of dangers, but none that compare to the atrocities they fled.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman carries her severely malnourished granddaughter in a clinic run by Doctors Without Borders in Sudd, a vast marshland in South Sudan. The area is now home to tens of thousands of desperate civilians who have fled a civil war.

item.title: American Prisoner in Yemen Said to Face Death Sentence
item.description: Sharif Mobley, who was arrested in 2010 in a sweep of suspected militants tied to Al Qaeda, told his lawyers that he could be sentenced even amid the country’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Unesco Rejects Kosovo Membership in a Victory for Serbia
item.description: Serbia had lobbied hard against Kosovo’s candidacy for the United Nations’ cultural agency, which had been supported by the major Western countries.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW BRUNWASSER

item.title: Russia Says Stalled Arms Deal With Iran Is Signed and Active
item.description: Russia said it was moving on a nearly 10-year-old contract with Iran to deliver powerful air defense missiles, though it gave no delivery date or any other details.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Memo From Europe: As China and Europe Age, Path to More Children Lies Beyond Bedroom
item.description: Simply allowing more offspring will not necessarily lead to a higher fertility rate, experts say, that is achieved by greater gender equality, more trust within society and higher immigration.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Parents and children in Beijing. Some experts said they believed that the new policy in China of allowing a second child would have only limited effect.
